fields.headline: United splash record £24.6m on Veron
fields.bodyText: Arsenal splashed out yet more money yesterday in pursuit of Premiership and Champions League success, but Manchester United continued to upstage them. United are poised to break the British transfer record for the second time in three months after finally agreeing personal terms with Juan Veron to seal a £24.6m move from Lazio last night. Arsenal signed Ipswichs England goalkeeper Richard Wright in a deal believed to be worth £6m. United have finalised a package that will make Veron the highest-paid player in the clubs history, with a weekly salary in excess of £80,000. The deal, which remains subject to Verons medical examination, will reaffirm Uniteds intent to match the financial muscle of their leading European rivals, having already signed Ruud van Nistelrooy from PSV Eindhoven for £19.5m. Sir Alex Ferguson is determined to mark his final year in office by returning the European Cup to Old Trafford and has apparently persuaded the clubs hierarchy to back him. He is still looking for a goalkeeper and a central defender. The 26-year-old Veron has built a reputation as one of the worlds most influential midfielders during his time in Serie A, with spells at Lazio, Parma and Sampdoria as well as a wealth of international experience with Argentina. He is expected to fly to England in the next couple of days for a medical at a private hospital in Cheshire. If all goes to plan, he will be introduced to his new teammates when they report for pre-season training on Monday. I dont foresee any problems, he said. Everything I have heard about Manchester United has been positive and I am looking forward to testing myself in England. This has removed a burden from me and naturally I am very satisfied. When he was acquitted last week of using falsified documents to obtain a European Union passport it opened the way for Uniteds chief executive Peter Kenyon to intensify the clubs efforts to lure him away from Rome. Internazionale, to name but one, launched a late attempt to beat Uniteds bid but seemingly to no avail. We have struck a deal with Manchester United. I would expect that everything is completed early next week, Lazios president Sergio Cragnotti confirmed yesterday, when it was also announced that he plans to quit the club and sell his controlling stake. Arsenals signing of the 23-year-old Wright could spell the end of the 37-year-old David Seamans first-team reign. We looked for somebody who can challenge David Seaman straight away, and I think Richard can do that, said their manager Arsène Wenger. But Feyenoord are not happy that Arsenal have jilted their Polish international goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek. They broke their agreement to sign Dudek and left us with a frustrated player, said their president Jorien van den Herik. If [the Arsenal vice-chairman David] Dein doesnt come up with a satisfactory explanation we may sue. Wenger said that Wright, who is understood to have signed a five-year deal, would be his last acquisition of the summer unless he could finalise a deal for the 21-year-old Gamba Osaka and the Japan midfielder Junichi Inamoto. Mustapha Hadji has signed a four-year deal with Aston Villa to complete a £4.5m move from Coventry that involves a part exchange with the £2.5m-rated Julian Joachim.
